description: Overview of existing device and manufacturing technologies in microelectronics, optoelectronics, magnetic storage, Microsystems, and biotechnology. Overview of near- and long-term challenges facing those fields. Near- and long-term prospects of nanoscience and related technologies for the evolutionary sustension of current approaches, and for the development of revolutionary designs and applications.
name: NANOSCALE SCIENCE & ENG

values.comments:
Nanoscale Science and Engineering provides an overview of existing device and
manufacturing technologies in microelectronics, optoelectronics, magnetic storage,
Microsystems, and biotechnology, along with an overview of near- and long-term
challenges facing those fields. Near- and long-term prospects of nanoscience and related
technologies for the evolutionary sustention of current approaches, and for the
development of revolutionary designs and applications are discussed during this course.
Students viewed this class as “very insightful” and “enjoyable.” This course was
well structured and covered a broad range of material, leaving students with a great deal
of “different kinds of nanomaterial” knowledge.
Students appreciated that Professor Kagan kept her Blackboard page so organized
and up-to-date; the notes and readings for this course were posted so that students could
read them before class and come prepared.
Overall, students appreciated this course, but wished that the material aligned
with the homework and tests better. The exams were often thought to be too long, and
students had a difficult time trying to follow some of the material if they had not been
exposed to semiconductor and transistor concepts before this course.
